Previously, only IOExceptions were caught and ignored. Now, all exceptions are caught, and if the exception is not an IOException, a BuildException is thrown. This commit updates the FullAnalyzer.java class to handle exceptions that may be thrown by BCEL's trunk, which no longer declares to throw an IOException. Title: [BEAM-10402] Enable checkerframework globally
Body: Instead of opting out whole modules now only existing classes are opted out of type checking. This has the following benefits:

 - New code will be checked, even in modules that are not yet passing.
 - Code won't as easily backslide in modules that were partially fixed.
 - It will produce much more manageable incremental work, and limitless starter bugs!

I produced the needed warnings (merged in other PRs) by removing the flag and then repeating the following, more or less:

```
./gradlew compileJava compileTestJava --continue 2>&1 | tee ~/tmp/gradle.log
 
cat ~/tmp/gradle.log \
    | grep -e "$PWD"'.*error:.*' \
    | cut -d : -f 1 \
    | sort -u \
    | xargs grep -L -e '^@SuppressWarnings' \
    | xargs sed -E -i '' 's/^(public +)?((abstract|final) +)?(class|interface)/@SuppressWarnings("nullness") &/'
  
./gradlew spotlessApply
```

There are two ways to still suppress type checking, arguments to `applyJavaNature`:

1. `generatedClassPatterns` to exclude various generated code that is not annotated with nullness types
2. `classesTriggerCheckerBugs` a map from classes which cannot be analyzed to their checkerframework bug URL

It first checks if the CFS is an index, and then gets the local ranges for the table associated with the CFS. It then iterates through the SSTableReaders, and for each one, it creates a CompactionController and checks if the SSTableReader intersects with the local ranges. If it does, it appends the compacted row to the SSTableWriter, and increments a counter for the total number of keys written. If the SSTableReader does not intersect with the local ranges, it replaces the compacted SSTable with an empty list, and continues to the next SSTableReader. The method also handles the case where the SSTableReader has indexes, and deletes the indexes for the row being compacted. The method also flushes the indexes for the CFS after the cleanup compaction is complete. The change in the method is that it no longer checks the expected range file size before creating a new SSTableWriter.

HM: make scanner.close idempotent
OMG: Refactor: Prevent multiple closings of files in BigTableScanner This commit introduces a new variable `isClosed` in the `BigTableScanner` class to track whether the data and index files have been closed. The `close()` method is modified to check this variable before closing the files. This change prevents the files from being closed multiple times, which could potentially lead to a NullPointerException as reported in issue CASSANDRA-9531.
AMG:
refactor: Refactor BigTableScanner.close() method to use AtomicBoolean for thread-safe file closure
This commit refactors the BigTableScanner.close() method to use a built-in concurrent mechanism (AtomicBoolean) to ensure that the files are closed only once and in a thread-safe manner. The design rationale for doing so is to avoid relying on a third-party utility (FileUtils) to close the files, which can lead to potential issues in multi-threaded environments. The usage of the method remains the same, but the method now also sets a flag indicating that the files are closed. The pre-condition for the method is that the input and output files are open, and the post-condition is that the input and output files are closed and the flag indicating that they are closed is set to true.

	at java.util.concurrent.ScheduledThreadPoolExecutor$ScheduledFutureTask.run(ScheduledThreadPoolExecutor.java:292)
	at java.util.concurrent.ThreadPoolExecutor.runWorker(ThreadPoolExecutor.java:1145)
	at java.util.concurrent.ThreadPoolExecutor$Worker.run(ThreadPoolExecutor.java:615)
	at java.lang.Thread.run(Thread.java:745)


The problem is due to the fact that when getTotalBufferSize is called the segment has already been desallocated. The reason being that the segment has been put twice in the queue of the CacheBucket.
I tracked down the problem to CompactionTask.runMayThrow which trigger 2 calls to the close method of BigTableScanner.
One here:

	at org.apache.cassandra.io.sstable.format.big.BigTableScanner.close(BigTableScanner.java:197)
	at org.apache.cassandra.db.compaction.AbstractCompactionStrategy$ScannerList.close(AbstractCompactionStrategy.java:333)
	at org.apache.cassandra.db.compaction.CompactionTask.runMayThrow(CompactionTask.java:207)


and the other here:

	at org.apache.cassandra.io.sstable.format.big.BigTableScanner.close(BigTableScanner.java:197)
	at org.apache.cassandra.utils.MergeIterator.close(MergeIterator.java:62)
	at org.apache.cassandra.db.compaction.CompactionTask.runMayThrow(CompactionTask.java:206)
Please consider them when writing the commit message.

HM: check for password attribute in all modifications

Previously, the method would apply the password hashing algorithm to the 'userPassword' attribute if it was present in the modification items. This change enhances the functionality of the method by preventing unnecessary operations.

If the operation is to remove the user password attribute, the method will not replace it with anything. This change ensures that the password attribute is not accidentally removed during a modify operation.

HM: Switched to TransferEnvelopeQueue for network queue management
OMG: Refactor: Improve handling of spilling queues in OutgoingConnection This commit refactors the OutgoingConnection class to improve the handling of spilling queues. The queuedEnvelopes object was changed from a Queue to a TransferEnvelopeQueue, and the registerSpillingQueue and unregisterSpillingQueue methods were modified to interact with this new object. These changes aim to enhance the management of overflow data.
AMG:
refactor: Refactor OutgoingConnection to use TransferEnvelopeQueue for spilling queue registration
This commit refactors the OutgoingConnection class to use the TransferEnvelopeQueue data structure for spilling queue registration. This change ensures that the registration process is thread-safe and simplifies the code by removing the need for a separate queue implementation. The pre-condition of the method is that a valid SpillingQueue object is provided. The post-condition is that the spilling queue is registered with the TransferEnvelopeQueue object.

refactor: Refactor MatchNode.computeStubCallsPerProcessedKey() to improve accuracy
This refactor changes the calculation of the callsPerKey variable in MatchNode.computeStubCallsPerProcessedKey(). The changes are made to potentially improve the accuracy of the results by taking the ratio of the total number of records to the estimated cardinality for each key, instead of the other way around. The method can still be used in the same way to compute the number of stub calls per processed key for a given Pact contract.

This change is intended to improve performance and predictability, and to ensure that the test is independent and does not rely on any state from a previous test run.

This change aims to make the code more efficient and easier to maintain.

Title: [FLINK-19533][checkpoint] Add channel state reassignment for unaligned checkpoints.
Body: <!--
*Thank you very much for contributing to Apache Flink - we are happy that you want to help us improve Flink. To help the community review your contribution in the best possible way, please go through the checklist below, which will get the contribution into a shape in which it can be best reviewed.*

*Please understand that we do not do this to make contributions to Flink a hassle. In order to uphold a high standard of quality for code contributions, while at the same time managing a large number of contributions, we need contributors to prepare the contributions well, and give reviewers enough contextual information for the review. Please also understand that contributions that do not follow this guide will take longer to review and thus typically be picked up with lower priority by the community.*

## Contribution Checklist

  - Make sure that the pull request corresponds to a [JIRA issue](https://issues.apache.org/jira/projects/FLINK/issues). Exceptions are made for typos in JavaDoc or documentation files, which need no JIRA issue.
  
  - Name the pull request in the form "[FLINK-XXXX] [component] Title of the pull request", where *FLINK-XXXX* should be replaced by the actual issue number. Skip *component* if you are unsure about which is the best component.
  Typo fixes that have no associated JIRA issue should be named following this pattern: `[hotfix] [docs] Fix typo in event time introduction` or `[hotfix] [javadocs] Expand JavaDoc for PuncuatedWatermarkGenerator`.

  - Fill out the template below to describe the changes contributed by the pull request. That will give reviewers the context they need to do the review.
  
  - Make sure that the change passes the automated tests, i.e., `mvn clean verify` passes. You can set up Azure Pipelines CI to do that following [this guide](https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/FLINK/Azure+Pipelines#AzurePipelines-Tutorial:SettingupAzurePipelinesforaforkoftheFlinkrepository).

  - Each pull request should address only one issue, not mix up code from multiple issues.
  
  - Each commit in the pull request has a meaningful commit message (including the JIRA id)

  - Once all items of the checklist are addressed, remove the above text and this checklist, leaving only the filled out template below.


**(The sections below can be removed for hotfixes of typos)**
-->

## What is the purpose of the change

Currently, recovery with rescaled channel state is failing. This PR enhances `StateAssignmentOperation` to reassignment channel state and create a channel state mapping, where channels before rescaling are mapped to channels after rescaling.

## Brief change log

- Refactors `StateAssignmentOperation` in preparation. In particular, it adds a two pass approach such that vertex may assign state of other vertexes.
- Adds `ChannelStateRescaler` to define rescaling behavior of in-flight data.
- Adds two properties to `StreamPartitioner` to return the `ChannelStateRescaler` for upstream and downstream side.
- Add upstream and downstream `ChannelStateRescaler`s to `JobEdge`, such that it is accessible to `StateAssignmentOperation`.
- Adding channel reassignment to `StateAssignmentOperation`.


## Verifying this change

Added unit tests. The final rescale PRs will also adapt `UnalignedCheckpointITCase` to cover rescaling.

## Does this pull request potentially affect one of the following parts:

  - Dependencies (does it add or upgrade a dependency): (yes / **no**)
  - The public API, i.e., is any changed class annotated with `@Public(Evolving)`: (**yes** / no)
  - The serializers: (yes / **no** / don't know)
  - The runtime per-record code paths (performance sensitive): (**yes** / no / don't know)
  - Anything that affects deployment or recovery: JobManager (and its components), Checkpointing, Kubernetes/Yarn/Mesos, ZooKeeper: (yes / **no** / don't know)
  - The S3 file system connector: (yes / **no** / don't know)

## Documentation

  - Does this pull request introduce a new feature? (**yes** / no)
  - If yes, how is the feature documented? (not applicable / docs / JavaDocs / **not documented**) (not finished yet)

Title: [FLINK-21400] Store attempt numbers outside ExecutionGraph
Body: Introduces a data structure to store the attempt numbers outside the ExecutionGraph. It's really just a simple Map<ExecutionVertexID, Integer> which ties a specific vertex+subtask to an attempt count.

Counts are set when an execution is registered at the EG, and retrieved when the ExecutionVertex creates a new Execution. The current attempt count is also still stored in the Execution, making the change less invasive (for example, resetForNewExecution continues to work without modifications).


One thing is that, as is, the semantics when it comes to rescaling are a bit funky.
ScaleUp:
If you begin with p=1 and an attempt count of 4, and then rescale to p=2, then what should the attempt count be for both subtasks?
In this version the attempt count for subtask 1 would be retained, while subtask 2 starts at 0.
Setting both to 0 would also make sense, but if we downscale again to p=1 then it would be nice if the attempt count had some relation to the original count.
Alternatively we could try to derive the attempt count for subtask 2 from other subtasks; in this example the obvious choice would be 2, because we're just replicating subtask 1.

ScaleDown:
The main issue arises when scaling down where the subtask with the largest index has the highest attempt count; currently this count would be lost. So you have p=2, and subtask 2 has an attempt count of 4, and now you scale down to p=1. The attempt count would now be solely determined by subtask 1, although we in essence just merged the two.


Overall, I don't think resetting attempt counts to 0 is an option, because they can be used to gauge the health of a vertex, and we'd run into collisions within metrics if we ever re-use a subtask+attempt combination.

The current approach is by far the simplest, and is the only option iff we want to adhere to these rules:
* every combination of subtask + attempt count is only used once
* the attempt counts for a given subtask over time always form a continuous series starting at 0

But I'm quite interested in what other people think about this.

The addition of the 'if (ctx.isReplicated())' check allows for the selection of a cluster group for replicated data nodes, and the addition of the 'forDataNodes(ctx.name()).forRandom()' allows for the selection of a random data node within the replicated context. The pre-condition is that the method requires a ClusterGroup object to be returned, and the post-condition is that the method returns a ClusterGroup object based on the given boolean value 'local' and the current context. If the current context is replicated, the method will return a cluster group for a random data node within the replicated context. If not, it will return the cluster group for local processing or null if not local processing.

HM: Moved the setting of the resovled flag in an object to before the call to the object store. This ensures that any recursive resolving will not attempt to resovlve the same object in an infinite loop
OMG: Refactor: Improve structure of `resolveImmediately` method in `LocalObjectManager.java` This commit refactors the `resolveImmediately` method in the `LocalObjectManager.java` file. The method now resolves the specified object immediately if it is persistent and not already resolved, and throws an exception if the object cannot be resolved. This change improves the structure of the code and makes it easier to understand.

refactor: Refactor LocalObjectManager: resolve-immediately method to handle non-persistent objects
This commit refactors the LocalObjectManager's resolve-immediately method to handle non-persistent objects. Previously, the method only resolved persistent objects. Now, if a non-persistent object is requested to be resolved, the method logs a debug message and returns without doing anything. This change allows for more flexibility in the system, as it allows for objects to be resolved even if they are not persistent.

HM: Remove Nova instance metadata limitRackspace cloud limits instance metadata to 5 key-value pairs, but upstream Nova only sets the limit at 128 by default.  This patch removes the limit entirely; the official python clients don't check it and the server is responsible for enforcing it anyway.
OMG: Fix: Remove limit on metadata key-value pairs in CreateServerOptions The previous implementation of the metadata method in the CreateServerOptions class had a limit on the number of key-value pairs that could be supplied per server. This commit removes that limit, in line with the findings of issue JCLOUDS-507 that Nova instance metadata is not limited to 5 pairs.
AMG:
refactor: Remove limit on custom server metadata
This commit removes the limit on the number of custom server metadata key-value pairs that can be supplied per server. The maximum size of the metadata key and value is each 255 bytes. This change allows for more flexibility when setting custom metadata for server creation requests.

-    * supplied per server is 5.
+    * is each 255 bytes.
     */

          checkArgument(
                entry.getKey().getBytes().length < 255,

This change ensures that the test accurately reflects the time taken by the HTTP sample and its sub-samples.

The usage of the method remains the same, as it is still testing the functionality of the SampleResult class.

refactor: Refactor SitetreeModule to use publication's site tree for trash node retrieval
This commit refactors the SitetreeModule to use the publication's site tree for retrieving the trash node, which may be more efficient or consistent with the rest of the codebase. The usage of the method remains the same, as it is used to retrieve the node object for a given document ID from the authoring, live, or trash trees of a publication. The change will affect the way the method retrieves the trash node. Instead of calling `publication.getSiteTree(Publication.TRASH_AREA)`, it will call `manager.getTree(Publication.TRASH_AREA)`. The method's property of returning the value of the given attribute for the given document remains the same. The available attributes are:

* AUTHORING_NODE: the authoring node
* LIVE_NODE: the live node
* TRASH_NODE: the trash node (now retrieved from the site tree provided by the publication instead of the site tree provided by the manager)

HM: Implement MutableLogEvent.createMemento()
OMG: Refactor: Update createMemento method in MutableLogEvent class The createMemento method in the MutableLogEvent class has been refactored. The method was previously creating a memento of the current log event state for later restoration. Now, it creates a memento of the current log event with the updated message. This change does not affect the external behavior or functionality of the method.
AMG:
refactor: Refactor MutableLogEvent.createMemento() to use a builder pattern
The method MutableLogEvent.createMemento() has been refactored to use a builder pattern instead of serialization and deserialization. This change makes the code more readable and maintainable, as the builder pattern allows for the creation of complex objects step by step. The `includeLocation` parameter is no longer used, and the new Log4jLogEvent object is created by calling the `memento()` method to get the message of the current Log4jLogEvent object and setting it as the message of the new Log4jLogEvent object using the builder pattern.

The HSSFSheet class represents a worksheet in an Excel file, and the changes allow for better understanding and manipulation of rows, cells, and sheet properties. No associated issues or pull requests were found for this commit.
AMG:
refactor: Refactor HSSFSheet.java: Improve readability and consistency of getFirstRowNum and getLastRowNum methods
This commit refactors the HSSFSheet.java file by improving the readability and consistency of the getFirstRowNum and getLastRowNum methods. The method names have been changed to better reflect their purpose, and the method descriptions have been updated to provide more information about the potential return values. Additionally, the method getLastRowNum now includes a note about the idiosyncrasies in the Excel file format and the potential need to call getPhysicalNumberOfRows to determine if there is a row at position zero.

diff --git a/src/java/org/apache/poi/hssf/usermodel/HSSFSheet.java b/src/java/org/apache/poi/hssf/usermodel/HSSFSheet.java
index e2e25c103..2b6ad4139 100644
--- a/src/java/org/apache/poi/hssf/usermodel/HSSFSheet.java
+++ b/src/java/org/apache/poi/hssf/usermodel/HSSFSheet.java
@@ -347,18 +347,25 @@ public final class HSSFSheet {
     }
 
     /**
-     * gets the first row on the sheet
-     * @return the number of the first logical row on the sheet
+     * Gets the first row on the sheet

-
     public int getFirstRowNum()
     {
         return firstrow;
     }
 
     /**
-     * gets the last row on the sheet
-     * @return last row contained n this sheet.
+     * Gets the number last row on the sheet.
+     * Owing to idiosyncrasies in the excel file

+     *  are zero rows on the sheet, or one at
+     *  position zero. For that case, additionally
+     *  call {@link #getPhysicalNumberOfRows()} to
+     *  tell if there is a row at position zero
+     *  or not. 
+     * @return the number of the last row contained in this sheet, zero based.
      */

The previous implementation used a `ByteArrayOutputStream` to write the workbook, which was then closed in a finally block. The NullOutputStream is used because it doesn't actually write the data to a file, it just allows the write() method to be called. The test still creates an Excel file with a sheet, adds two rows with cells containing 'blabla', and then uses the IOUtils.write() method to write the workbook to a NullOutputStream. The test still checks the cell reference range in the workbook's dimension.

HM: tuple() -> new Values()
OMG: Refactor: Refactored tuple emission in TwitterSampleSpout In the `nextTuple()` method of `TwitterSampleSpout.java`, the way tuples are emitted has been refactored for improved code structure. The method still retrieves and emits the next tuple from the queue, or sleeps for 50 milliseconds if the queue is empty. However, the tuple emission is now done using `new Values(ret)` instead of `tuple(ret)`. This change does not affect the functionality of the method.
AMG:
refactor: Refactor TwitterSampleSpout.java: Simplify tuple emission
This commit refactors the TwitterSampleSpout.java file by simplifying the tuple emission process. Instead of using the `tuple()` method to wrap the message, it now uses the `new Values(ret)` constructor directly. This change aims to improve code readability and maintainability.

refactor: Refactor SocketWrapper for concurrent, thread-safe socket management
This commit refactors the SocketWrapper class to manage socket connections in a concurrent, thread-safe manner. The changes include making the comet, async, upgraded, and keptAlive properties volatile, ensuring that they are thread-safe. This refactoring improves the overall performance and scalability of the application.

This change does not affect the functionality of the method, but it optimizes the write process.

AMG:
refactor: Introduce conditional JMX notification for slow queries
This commit refactors the SlowQueryReportJmx class to allow for more control over when the JMX notification is sent for slow queries. The isLogSlow() method has been introduced to determine when to send the JMX notification.

The EntityIndexBatch now includes a delete method that deletes all documents from ES with the same entity Id. These changes aim to improve the overall performance and scalability of the system.

OMG: Feat: Add new getMarkupParser method and update loadMarkup method This commit introduces a new method, getMarkupParser, in Application.java. This method creates a new instance of the markup parser, configures it with the current settings, and sets the base page for autolinking.  The loadMarkup method in Container.java has been updated to use the new getMarkupParser method. This change enhances the functionality of the loadMarkup method by allowing it to load the markup for a given application and key, read the markup from the provided resource, store it in the markup cache, and then return the markup.  These changes contribute to the overall functionality and efficiency of the application.

refactor: Refactor markup parsing in Application and Container classes
This commit refactors the markup parsing process in the Application and Container classes. The Application class now initializes a markup parser with the given page, allowing for different markup parsers to be used depending on the current page. The Container class now uses the markup parser associated with the current page when loading markup from a resource. A new method, getMarkupParser(Page page), is added to the Application class to obtain the markup parser instance. The deleted method, getMarkupParser(), is no longer needed as it is replaced by the new method.

HM: Fixes NPE when sessions are invalidated *outside* a request, e.g. due to session timeout
OMG: Refactor: Improve session destruction handling in RequestLogger This commit refactors the `sessionDestroyed` method in `RequestLogger.java` to handle the event of a session being destroyed more robustly. Previously, the method directly removed the session with the given session id from the live sessions and set the removed session data as metadata in the current request cycle. This commit adds a null check for `RequestCycle` before setting the metadata, preventing potential null pointer exceptions.
AMG:
refactor: Refactor sessionDestroyed method to store session data before removal
This commit refactors the sessionDestroyed method to store the session data in a variable before removing it from the live sessions map. This allows for potential future use or further processing of the session data. The check for `requestCycle` being null has been added to prevent null pointer exceptions.
